snippet.textDisplay: Why do we insist on a sewage system? Why can't we have all waste converted to a solid waste collection system that expands on municipal garbage collection?
snippet.textOriginal: Why do we insist on a sewage system? Why can't we have all waste converted to a solid waste collection system that expands on municipal garbage collection?

snippet.textDisplay: @Interdimensional the energy to heat and treat the solid waste can be immediately reused to heat or cool water. The economics of scale of manufacturing a waste treatment appliance would be far more efficient than the construction of the sewage system and a collective treatment plant
snippet.textOriginal: @Interdimensional the energy to heat and treat the solid waste can be immediately reused to heat or cool water. The economics of scale of manufacturing a waste treatment appliance would be far more efficient than the construction of the sewage system and a collective treatment plant

snippet.textDisplay: @jiunn wong Like I said, your idea gets rid of the economy of scale, and adds complexity and cost.  Do you think energy is free?
snippet.textOriginal: @jiunn wong Like I said, your idea gets rid of the economy of scale, and adds complexity and cost.  Do you think energy is free?

snippet.textDisplay: @Interdimensional thats why you heat it up to dehydrate it. The heat will sanitize the solid waste and reduce its mass instantly at the source. The waste heat can then be use to heat water or run a absorption cycle cooling system
snippet.textOriginal: @Interdimensional thats why you heat it up to dehydrate it. The heat will sanitize the solid waste and reduce its mass instantly at the source. The waste heat can then be use to heat water or run a absorption cycle cooling system

snippet.textDisplay: @Jonas Stahl those produce grey water waste, which can be easily processed for non portable use on site, or safely discarded into the stormwater system, negating the need for a sewer
snippet.textOriginal: @Jonas Stahl those produce grey water waste, which can be easily processed for non portable use on site, or safely discarded into the stormwater system, negating the need for a sewer

snippet.textDisplay: @jiunn wong You need a sewage system for you shower, washing machine... anyway, why use two different system when you could just use one.
snippet.textOriginal: @jiunn wong You need a sewage system for you shower, washing machine... anyway, why use two different system when you could just use one.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Interdimensional I think your perspective is misguided by paradigm.  You just need to poop in a bucket.  Heat the bucket to remove water and pathogens, and empty that bucket into the trash. That's all.

The current sewage system is the expensive, difficult to build and maintain solution
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: @jiunn wong So build a bunch of expensive infrastructure, instead of using the simple as dirt solution of sewers, that have been around since Roman times? Elon Musk might like your idea
snippet.textOriginal: @jiunn wong So build a bunch of expensive infrastructure, instead of using the simple as dirt solution of sewers, that have been around since Roman times? Elon Musk might like your idea

snippet.textDisplay: @jiunn wong that's blackwater, not potable water. My question though was how do you plan to remove the water.
snippet.textOriginal: @jiunn wong that's blackwater, not potable water. My question though was how do you plan to remove the water.

snippet.textDisplay: @Interdimensional we already have those trucks for solid garbage. Each adult human only produce 2 lbs of fecal matter a day. Remove the water, and that is a bucket of solid waste a week, easily absorbed by a truck collection system. Dehydration process can also sanitize the fecal matter, you only need to engineer a bathroom appliance
snippet.textOriginal: @Interdimensional we already have those trucks for solid garbage. Each adult human only produce 2 lbs of fecal matter a day. Dehydration process can also sanitize the fecal matter, you only need to engineer a bathroom appliance

snippet.textDisplay: @joshua cheung remove the water First! Some 95% of sewage mass is water, which is a huge waste of portable water to begin with
snippet.textOriginal: @joshua cheung remove the water First! Some 95% of sewage mass is water, which is a huge waste of portable water to begin with

snippet.textDisplay: In most areas, sewage is passively carried by wastewater flows that require only gravity, not pumps.  But even a pumped system is far more efficient and environmentally friendly than mobilizing thousands of trucks to collect sewage. (and paying the drivers, paying for upkeep, etc.)
snippet.textOriginal: In most areas, sewage is passively carried by wastewater flows that require only gravity, not pumps.  But even a pumped system is far more efficient and environmentally friendly than mobilizing thousands of trucks to collect sewage. (and paying the drivers, paying for upkeep, etc.)

snippet.textDisplay: There's a lot of water to process. What you gonna do with it?
